frameDefinitions: This frame deals with a Speaker communicating a reply or response, a Message, to some prior communication or action, the Trigger.  '' 'The landlord has not yet replied in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.
This frame contains words for types of noise which can be used to characterize verbal communication.
A Speaker addresses an Audience on a particular Topic.
In this frame, a Communicator judges the Addressee and then communicates that appraisal directly to the Addressee.
frameExamples: The landlord has not yet <t>replied</t> in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.DNI
'Don't treat me as a child!' she <t>cried</t> scornfully.
McNamara <t>addressed</t> congress on the state of affairs of the Department of Defense.
The principal <t>rebuked</t> the student for cheating on the exam.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that communicates the reply or response. It is expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of a <t>Target</t> verb or as the Genitive modifier of a <t>Target</t> noun:
This is the person to whom the response is communicated.  When expressed, this role occurs as the direct object of a <t>Target</t> verb, or in a prepositional phrase introduced by 'to':
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>. It can be expressed as a direct quote or a clause.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs quite rarely in this frame and usually only as a PP Complement of a noun <t>Target</t>:
The <fen>Trigger</fen> is the prior communication or action to which a response is given. It can occur as an NP Object or a PP Complement.
The time interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes their verbal response.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  makes a verbal response.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:
<fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that delivers the <fen>Message</fen>.
Message has a number of different realizations in this frame, including <ment>that</ment>-clauses, direct quotes, infinitival complements, <ment>for-to</ment> phrases, and NP Objects.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs in PP Complements, usually headed by <ment>about</ment>.
The <fen>Voice</fen> describes the <fex name=''>Speaker'</fex>s utterance or other message-encoded production.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> where the Communication noise event occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where an event occurs.
The person or persons to whom the <fen>Speaker</fen> delivers their text.
The person who orally delivers a text about a <fen>Topic</fen> to a passive <fen>Audience</fen>.
What the text that the <fen>Speaker</fen> produces is about.
The <fen>Time</fen> describes when the speaking occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location where the speaking occurs.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates a judgment to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The <fen>Addressee</fen> is jduged by the <fen>Communicator</fen> and receives the message of approval or disapproval.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject on which the <fen>Addressee</fen> is being judged.
The <fen>Reason</fen> is why the Communicator forms the type of judgment they form.
The <fen>Medium</fen> identifies the physical or abstract entity in which the judgment is conveyed.
An action or entity under the control of the <fen>Communicator</fen> that expresses the criticism or praise directed towards the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The point in time at which the <fen>Communicator</fen> berates or compliments the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Communicator</fen> admonishes the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Sue</fex> responded to the objection convincingly.
Sue answered <fex>Bob</fex> immediately.
<fex>'I can't help you,'</fex> Sue answered.
My boss still hasn't given me an answer <fex>about a promotion</fex>.
Sue answered <fex>the question</fex>.
A reminder letter was sent to all nonrespondents who had not replied <fex>after 28 days</fex>.
This was how Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Jayalalithaa responded <fex>in the Assembly</fex> on November 5, 2003.
<fex>The teacher</fex> phrased the question carefully.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
Kim formulated her objections <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>Kim</fex> whined that it wasn't fair.
Kim whined <fex>that it wasn't fair</fex>.
Kim howled <fex>about the unfairness of it all</fex>.
<fex>John's voice</fex> bellowed for her to be quiet.
He lectured <fex>to the officers of the Scots Guard</fex>  in  1929.
<fex>You</fex> have to sermonize about the good times
He was the Director: he could lecture <fex>on whomever he liked</fex>.
The teacher scolded the children <fex>about their meessy cookie eating</fex>.
The principal rebuked the student <fex>for cheating on the exam</fex>.
Though she had killed him so long ago, she could still see his jeering <fex>smile</fex>.
She complimented me <fex>almost every morning</fex> on my smart starched shirts.
We were scolded <fex>in the kitchen</fex> by the biggest cook you've ever seen.
